captions.text:
This was my first time attending an E3 in
person, and as I sat down in the audience

of the Microsoft presser, I realised how much
you miss watching these things online, as

the camera swept across the rows of hooting
paid fanboys in the front rows and very deliberately

avoided tracking over the bored-looking media
types that filled the other two thirds of
the room along with a stench of cheap cigarettes.

Anyway, the big news is that the new Xbox,
Project Scarletu-tu, isn&#39;t coming out &#39;til

last quarter 2020 so, back to sleep everyone,
until the next E3 when they&#39;ll really bring

the system sellers out and presumably come
up with an even worse name for the fucking
thing.

Until then all we have is that Halo Infinite
is about Master Chief being found lost in

space yet-a-fucking-gain, they really need
to put one of those GPS keyfinders on that

green cunt, and Gears of War 5 will involve
chest high walls and dudes with necks twice
as thick as the tops of their heads.

Scant mention of the story campaign, probably
&#39;cos it&#39;ll be the same boring shit as always,

but I did get a chance to play the new Escape
multiplayer mode enough to establish that

it&#39;s just Left 4 Dead with Gears of War combat,
set in a map so boring and labyrinthine I

was astonished to learn it wasn&#39;t randomly
generated.
So what would you call it, Gear 4 Dead?
Or Left of War?

Or does that sound too much like you&#39;re giving
directions?

As for streaming your games to your device
wherever you are, who the fuck carries an
Xbox controller everywhere they go?

Besides boomerang enthusiasts with very poor
eyesight?

What&#39;s more important is all these game subscription
services, your Xbox Game Pass and your Uplay

Plus, which I don&#39;t mind that much &#39;cos in
this age of Netflix the financial model for

video games has to change at some point from
its current state, the financial model of
an abattoir built on the edge of a cliff.

But in the end it&#39;s only the games that count,
and the Xbox briefing broke new records for

sheer number of announced games whose titles
I almost immediately forgot.

I think there was an indie game with pastel
colours and sad piano music at one point.

And I think there was something involving
guns and the colour magenta.

Oh hang on, I don&#39;t have to rely upon half-remembered
online clips this year &#39;cos I actually played

some of the thing I&#39;m very naughtily pretending
to forget was called Bleeding Edge.

And I hereby declare that it&#39;s making a heroic
effort to not immediately look like a copy
of Overwatch.

Yes, it&#39;s a team-based competitive hero shooter,
but this one&#39;s focused on melee combat.
Oh, it&#39;s all melee?
Um.
No.
Some characters are ranged.
So, like Overwatch, then.
Moving on.
Wait!
We gave everyone a surfboard!
I already said moving on, Bleeding Edge.

Funny, isn&#39;t it, how whenever a game talks
about being &quot;over the top&quot; or &quot;tongue in cheek&quot;

that always seems to mean the same thing these
days - that it&#39;s going to look like an irresponsibly

violent version of Jet Set Radio, probably
cel shaded, every character is introduced

with freeze frame profiles and dresses like
a Tank Girl cosplayer with color blindness
and a lot of things will be magenta.

Oh yeah, and there&#39;ll be a panda for some
reason.

That was the case with Contra Rogue Corps,
which started with a ker-razy cutscene culminating

in our main dude riding a missile into the
level spraying bullets like a giant incontinent

doom cock, only for the gameplay to start
and everything screeched to a halt as I moved

sluggishly around the isometric level spitting
bullets from a gun that overheated faster

than a former Trump associate in a police
interview room and took about as long to cool
down as an impeachment proceeding.

But let&#39;s get onto some of the bigger stuff,
like for example the giant dribbling cock

that Square Enix tripped and broke its nose
on, the one with &quot;Avengers&quot; written along
the side.

With Avengers Endgame and the very distinct
appearances of the main actors still fresh

in public memory, wheeling out a game starring
their stunt doubles left everyone a bit nonplussed
at best.

&quot;Oh come on, Yahtz, the cost of tehe likeness
rights for those people could have paid for

four more years of mysteriously silent Final
Fantasy 7 development.&quot;

Oh fair enough, Square Enix, just show us
how the Avengers game plays, then.
&quot;Mmmmm... no.&quot;

Between that being a blatant grab for some
of the sweet cash that drools constantly from

Marvel&#39;s cornucopic vagina, and everything
else they had being one remade or rereleased

pretty anime sword boy game after another,
the motto of Square Enix this year was &quot;Isn&#39;t
not having to come up with ideas great?&quot;

Now then, my Bethesda booth visit was a rather
strange adventure.

I had one hour to see Wolfenstein Youngblood
and Doom Eternal, and after forty-five minutes

of Wolfenstein&#39;s long boring cutscenes, irritating
bullet sponge combat and further evidence

for the truth of the old saying, &quot;crowbarred-in
co-op enhances a previously single player

narrative-focused experience the way a handful
of broken glass enhances cosmetic dentistry,&quot;
our time was running a bit tight.

&quot;Oh, well, I suppose I could switch you to
Doom early, Wolfenstein did still have a whole

other level to bore you to death with, but
if you insist.&quot;

So I switched to Doom, and Doom proceeded
to kick whatever shredded remnants of arse
remained unkicked from the last game.

So altogether the Bethesda hour was like opening
a present that was been wrapped in ten layers
of moist bog roll.

Doom Eternal was how you fucking do an E3
demo.

Hands on, quick tutorial, straight into the
primary loop to let it speak for itself in

the voice of a very handsome man with a thick
but somehow reassuring smell clinging to his
body hair.
Not like all those fucking hands-off demos.

I still have no fucking clue if Dying Light
2 and Cyberpunk 2077 will still look impressive

when being played by someone who isn&#39;t following
the same rigidly choreographed script they&#39;ve

gone through thirty times today, who might
inconveniently look in the wrong direction

when something impressive happens or want
to operate on an actual fucking learning curve.

Hey, maybe Cyberpunk could have had the money
to get the game finished a little quicker

if they&#39;d just paid Keanu Reeves to come onto
the Xbox conference and say nine words instead
of ten.

Wait a minute, everyone - Yahtzee thought
Doom Eternal looked good?
Fuck!
Going to E3 has given him hype disease!

Get him in quarantine before the infection
spreads and he starts using the phrase &quot;it
could be interesting.&quot;
Fine, you want cynicism?
Pokemon Sword and Shield.

Run out of colours and gemstones and chromosomes
it&#39;s down to weapons, soon household objects

and perhaps one day we&#39;ll get to live the
dream of playing Pokemon Cock and Balls.
But I digress.
The full 3D look really isn&#39;t suiting Pokemon.

Everything looks so small in a huge empty
world and the animations and interfaces all

come across as kinda stiff and awkward, like
they&#39;ve all had to hold a pose for just a
little bit too long before the photo was taken.
And as for a Zelda Breath of the Wild sequel.

So much for the bold spirit of back to basics
innovation that drove the first one, now it&#39;s

straight back to endlessly stirring the fucking
pot for Nintendo.

Hence Link&#39;s Awakening being copy-pasted as
a fucking Happy Meal toy, I suppose.

Mind you, direct sequels to Zelda games doing
their own thing now the tiresome &quot;save princess

from Ganon&quot; formalities are out of the way
have historically been the breeding ground

for some of the really good Zeldas like Link&#39;s
Awakening or Majora&#39;s Mask so actually a Breath

of the Wild sequel could be intere- ALRIGHT
LOCK IT DOWN CONTAINMENT BREACH
John Romero&#39;s new bitch
